habitat_description:
Southwest:
This species is endemic to the mountains of Baja California in Mexico and the San Bernadino and San Jacinto mountains of southern California (Best and Granai 1994, Wilson and Ruff 1999). Its habitats include pinyon-juniper, chamise-redshank, mixed chapparal and ponderosa pine. It is abundant in these vegetation associations at elevations from 760 m to 2600 m. It is uncommon in valley foothill hardwoods and Joshua tree habitats at lower elevations ([Duke and Shelhammer 2007] based on Zeiner et al. 1990). In the San Bernadino mountains, this species is found along dry northern slopes of pinyon woodlands to coniferous forests at higher elevations (Blankenship 1985). This species is abundant in the desert slopes and ranges of the San Bernadino mountains east to Joshua Tree National Monument among the arid, rocky, upper Sonoran pinyon-juniper woodlands above 2100 m elevation. Tamias obscurus is also associated with ponderosa pine, sugar pine, white fir, Englemann oak, incense cedar, and serviceberry. Additionally, the California chipmunk occurs at lower elevations in live oak and chapparal habitats (Callahan 1976, Callahan 1977, Miller and Stebbins 1964, Best and Granai 1994).
